item.title: Discrete Mathematics: Logic and Proofs
item.author: Author
item.description: 1. Propositions A proposition is a declarative sentence (that is, a sentence that declares a fact) that is either true or false, but not both. Examples: Toronto is the capital of Canada -> This is a proposition (and it’s false) 1 + 1 = 2 -> This is a proposition (and it’s true) What is the capital of the US? -> This is not a proposition because it is not declarative x + 1 = 2
